sentence: Ingram Micro Inc.IM recently announced that Heartland Technology Solutions (HTS) - a managed IT services provider - has selected its Service Desk and Cloud Ignite Services to provide customers with extensive support.
The financial terms of the deal have not been made public.
HTS is a managed service provider (MSP), serving more than 650 customers.
It helps clients to create trustworthy and efficient IT environments, thereby increasing network reliability and improving client efficiency.
Ingram Micro's Service Desk provides cost effective, scalable and quality driven services that allow partners to boost output and profitability, thereby positively impacting their business.
It features quick response, one-call resolution with phone, email and chat support.
On the other hand, its Cloud Marketplace is a global platform through which channel partners and professionals can avail the required cloud services.
The Ingram Micro Cloud Marketplace has more than 200 cloud-based solutions from over 70 vendors including salesforce.com CRM , VMware VMW and AVG Technologies.
Notably, HTS has started vending Microsoft MSFT Office 365 through the Ingram Micro Cloud Marketplace via the Microsoft Cloud Solution Provider (CSP) program.

HTS believes that selecting Ingram Micro's value-driven support offerings will be extremely beneficial for the company as it will enhance customers' overall support experience and accelerate the growth of its cloud businesses.
Also, HTS will be able to market its products easily and expand in newer markets by leveraging Ingram Micro's distribution channels and reach out to new customers.
On the contrary, the agreement will broaden Ingram Micro's capabilities as a cloud solution provider, thereby helping it to capitalize on the increasing opportunities in the cloud computing market.
The partnership will also be a good source of monthly recurring revenues for Ingram Micro.
Both Ingram Micro and HTS are positive about the partnership and look forward to tapping the prospects in the cloud services market.
We believe that the distributor partnership will prove to be a win-win situation for both the companies.
Ingram Micro has been striking distribution deals with a number of original equipment manufacturers thus expanding its product portfolio.
Moreover, Ingram Micro's portfolio of cloud computing products is expected to remain its key growth driver.
However, not all is hunky dory for the distributor.
While its services business is seeing encouraging growth, the company remains largely dependent on the PC market where shipments remain sluggish.
According to the latest IDC report, PC shipments are expected to decline 6.2% in 2015, greater than the earlier projection of a 4.9% decline.
